body: we first need to consolidate the multivariate forecasting interface, see #919 and #228
but yes, important next step - join the dev days if interested #863
I'm very glad to know, thank you for the feedback

issue.title: Forecasting support for multivariate y and multiple input/output types - working prototype

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This is a merge/review ready sketch for how multivariate `y` could be supported for multivariate forecasters, alongside the possibility to pass `np.array` and `pd.Series`. This is based on the design in [STEP no.5](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/tree/main/steps/05_scitype_based_IO_checks), adapted to the new forecasting base class.

The key ingredient are:

* converters parameterized by from, to, and as - in the `convertIO`module. Besides the obvious conversion functionality, the converters can be given access to a dictionary via reference in the `store` argument, where information for inverting lossy conversions (like from `pd.DataFrame` to `np.array`) can be stored
* a new tag `y_type` which encodes the type of `y` that the private `_fit`, `_predict`, and `_update` assume internally - for now, it's just one type and not a list of compatible types
* some logic in the public "plumbing" area of `fit`, `predict`, `update`, which converts inputs to the public layer to the desired input of the logic layer and back

This is for discussion, and I expect major change before we merge.

It might be especially interesting to discuss the following interaction with typing:
the third argument of the converter, the "as" argument, is a scitype, and designed to have the same name as the respective `typing` composite type. Also see discussion in #965, #973 and #974.

Thinking of the logical continuation of this:

* extend this to the other arguments, e.g., `X`
* the individual argument checks like `check_X` etc should be replaced by checks of the kind `check(what, as : scitype)`, e.g., `check(y, "Series")` should replace the less generic `check_y`.
* extend this to time series classification, to support 3D numpy arrays, awkward arrays, nested data frames

A "visionary" pathway may see this working with type annotations that are scitypes, not `typing` machine types, e.g.,
```python
fit(X : Series, Y : Series)
etc
_fit(X: Series, Y : UnivariateSeries)
```
and checks/conversions being done automatically.

body:
As discussed in the latest mentoring meeting @thayeylolu will be working on this.

The interface will assume `pd.DataFrame` as input to `_fit`, and as return from `_predict`, no other types for the moment.

This means it should eventually be compatible irrespective of whichever of the two proposed designs #980 and #1074 we go with.

FYI, @mloning.

Other implementation notes

* we should start by writing a short user journey design
* the statsmodels adapter may be a good way to go, but needs investigating
* tests may also need looking at, e.g., multivariate input generation

issue.title: Add wrapper for statsmodels VAR

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/929


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR aims to wrap the Vector Auto Regressor in Statmodels


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
none

task

- [x] Wrap VAR
- [x]  Accepts only DataFrames
- [x] Write Test
- [ ] Write a test with hyper parameters 

#### Changes implemented by @aiwalter 
- Implemented in-sample prediction by means of residuals
- Added `n_columns` param to forecasting and estimator tests, so that either `_make_series` or `make_forecasting_problem` gets `n_columns` based on tag value `scitype:y`
- Added predict with `X`

body:
##### USER JOURNEY DESIGN
-----
**Vector Auto Regressor**

**Primary use case** :Vector Auto Regression of a data frame with more one columns
**Input Type** : None

###### Methods
- fit (y,fh)
```python
-fit(y: dataframe, X:None, fh:np.ndarray, pd.Series)
- predict(self, fh, X=None, return_pred_int=False, alpha=DEFAULT_ALPHA)
```
   - expected input : `y`,`fh`
   - expected output: `self`
```python
- predict()
```
  - inherits from `_StatsModelsAdapter`
  - expected output: `pd.dataframe`


``` python

model = VAR()
model.fit(y=y, fh=fh, X=X)
model.predict()

```

#### Wrapped VAR

``` python
model = VAR(**params)
model.fit(y=y, fh=fh, X=X)
model.predict(X)
```
#### Statsmodel's VAR
```
model = VAR(endog = y, exog = X)
statvar = model.fit(**params)
statvar.forecast(y=forecast_input, steps=fh, exog_future = X)
```

this is not a complete user journey design - this should include specification, and usage (e.g., fitting, forecasting) in key use cases.

I also don't think that data should ever be passed to a constructor - look at the forecasting extension template, constructor arguments are reserved to be hyper-parameters and components (if any)
Hi @fkiraly , I have updated the User Journey

issue.title: Add wrapper for statsmodels VECM

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference Issues/PRs
Issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/929


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
This PR aims to wrap the VECM in Statmodels


#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?
none

task

- [x] Wrap VECM
- [x]  Accepts only DataFrames
- [x] Write Test
- [  ] Write a test with hyper parameters

body:
just confirming what I said verbally earlier, the user journey should probably look like this:
```params
model = VAR(**params)
model.fit(y=y, fh=fh, X=X)
model.predict(X_new)
```

where `model.predict(X_new)` returns a data frame at indices of `fh`, and both `y` and `X` are data frame
